topics.name: Rights and Responsibilities
topics.summary: Canadian citizens have rights and responsibilities that come from our history, are secured by Canadian law, and reflect our shared traditions, identity and values.
keyFacts: Magna Carta (1215) established an 800-year tradition of ordered liberty
Habeas corpus is the right to challenge unlawful detention by the state (from English common law)
Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms was entrenched in 1982
Two key documents of rights and freedoms: the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms and the Magna Carta
Fundamental freedoms include: conscience/religion, thought/expression, peaceful assembly, association
Charter also protects: Mobility Rights, Multiculturalism, and Aboriginal peoples' rights
Mobility Rights allow Canadians to live and work anywhere in Canada, travel freely, and obtain passports
French and English have equal status in Parliament and government
Men and women are equal under the law
Canada does not tolerate: spousal abuse, honour killings, female genital mutilation, or forced marriage
RESPONSIBILITIES:
Six responsibilities: obeying the law, taking responsibility for oneself and family, serving on a jury, voting in elections, helping others in the community, protecting heritage and environment
Serving on a jury when called is the only legally mandatory responsibility
Voting is both a right and a responsibility (moral duty, not legally required)
Volunteering is an example of community participation
Taking responsibility for yourself and family means: getting a job, taking care of family, working hard in keeping with one's abilities
Indigenous peoples gained the right to vote in federal elections in 1960 (without losing status)

topics.name: Who We Are
topics.summary: To understand what it means to be Canadian, it is important to know about our three founding peoples: Aboriginal, French and British.
keyFacts: Three founding peoples: Aboriginal, French, and British
Aboriginal peoples are the first people to live in Canada
ABORIGINAL PEOPLES:
Aboriginal peoples include: First Nations (65%), Metis (30%), and Inuit (4%)
There are over 630 First Nations bands and about 600 reserves across Canada
Band chiefs and councillors have major responsibilities on First Nations reserves
Inuit means 'the people' in Inuktitut
Metis are a distinct people of mixed Aboriginal and European ancestry (mostly in Prairie provinces)
Metis developed their own language called Michif (mixing French nouns with Cree verbs)
Royal Proclamation of 1763 first guaranteed Aboriginal territorial rights
Residential Schools (1800s-1980s): Aboriginal children were placed in schools to assimilate them; schools were poorly funded and language/cultural practices were prohibited
Federal government formally apologized for residential schools in 2008
FRENCH CANADIANS:
Approximately 7 million Francophones (French-speaking people) in Canada
Acadians are descendants of French colonists who settled in Maritimes (1604)
Acadians survived the Great Upheaval deportations (1755-1763); many went to Louisiana (became Cajuns)
Quebecers form a nation within a united Canada (recognized 2006)
LANGUAGE AND DIVERSITY:
English and French are Canada's two official languages
A Francophone is a person who speaks French as their first language
New Brunswick (NB) is the only officially bilingual province
The great majority of Canadians identify as Christian (Catholic is the largest denomination)
Since 1970s, most immigrants have come from Asian countries
Chinese railroad workers played an important part in building the Canadian Pacific Railway
NOTABLE FIGURES:
General Sir Arthur Currie: Canada's greatest soldier in the First World War
Sir Sam Steele: great frontier hero, Mounted Policeman, and soldier (Klondike Gold Rush)

topics.name: Canada's History
topics.summary: Canada has a rich history from Aboriginal peoples through European exploration, Confederation, and nation-building.
keyFacts: EARLY EXPLORATION:
Vikings reached Labrador and Newfoundland about 1,000 years ago (L'Anse aux Meadows, UNESCO site)
John Cabot mapped Canada's Atlantic coast in 1497
Jacques Cartier explored St. Lawrence River (1534-1542); name Canada from Iroquoian word 'kanata' (village)
Samuel de Champlain founded Quebec City in 1608, known as 'Father of New France'
BRITISH RULE:
Battle of the Plains of Abraham (1759): Britain defeated France, ending France's empire in America
Both generals died at the Plains of Abraham: British General Wolfe and French General Montcalm
Quebec Act of 1774: allowed Catholic freedom, French civil law, and British criminal law
United Empire Loyalists: 40,000+ people loyal to British Crown fled American Revolution to Canada
Constitutional Act of 1791: granted first elected legislative assemblies in Canada
First representative assembly elected in Halifax (1758)
ABOLITION AND FREEDOM:
Upper Canada (Ontario) was first province in British Empire to move toward abolishing slavery (1793), led by Lt. Governor John Graves Simcoe
Underground Railroad: Christian anti-slavery network that helped thousands of slaves escape to Canada
WAR OF 1812:
War of 1812: United States invaded Canada but was defeated
Battle of Queenston Heights (1812): Major General Sir Isaac Brock died in this victory
Laura Secord (1813): pioneer who walked 30 km to warn Lt. James FitzGibbon of an American attack
British forces burned the White House in Washington, D.C. in 1814
Major figures: Sir Isaac Brock, Chief Tecumseh (Shawnee ally), Laura Secord
RESPONSIBLE GOVERNMENT:
Rebellions of 1837-38 led to Lord Durham's Report recommending responsible government
Sir Louis-Hippolyte La Fontaine: champion of French language rights, first leader of responsible government in Canada (1849), worked alongside Robert Baldwin
CONFEDERATION:
The Fathers of Confederation worked together to create the Dominion of Canada
Confederation: July 1, 1867 (British North America Act, now Constitution Act, 1867)
Four founding provinces: Ontario (ON), Quebec (QC), Nova Scotia (NS), New Brunswick (NB)
July 1 was called Dominion Day until 1982, now called Canada Day
Province of Canada was split into Ontario and Quebec at Confederation
Sir John A. Macdonald: first Prime Minister (born in Scotland, portrait on $10 bill)
Sir George-Etienne Cartier: key architect of Confederation from Quebec, led Quebec into Confederation
WESTERN DEVELOPMENT:
Louis Riel: led Metis uprising at Fort Garry (1869-70), father of Manitoba
North West Mounted Police (later RCMP) established in 1873
Canadian Pacific Railway completed November 7, 1885; Donald Smith (Lord Strathcona) drove the last spike at Craigellachie, BC
Chinese head tax: discriminatory entry fee for Chinese immigrants (1885-1923); Canada apologized in 2006
Sir Wilfrid Laurier: first French-Canadian PM since Confederation (portrait on $5 bill), encouraged western immigration
WORLD WAR I (1914-1918):
Over 600,000 Canadians served; approximately 60,000 died
Battle of Vimy Ridge: April 9, 1917 (Vimy Day), 10,000 Canadian casualties, called 'birth of a nation'
General Sir Arthur Currie commanded the Canadian Corps at Vimy Ridge
Lt.-Col. John McCrae wrote 'In Flanders Fields' (1915), which inspired the remembrance poppy
WOMEN'S SUFFRAGE:
Women's suffrage movement: the effort by women to achieve the right to vote
Dr. Emily Stowe founded the women's suffrage movement in Canada
Manitoba was the first province to grant women voting rights in 1916
Women gained federal vote in 1918; Agnes Macphail became first female MP in 1921
WORLD WAR II (1939-1945):
Over one million Canadians served; 44,000 died
D-Day: June 6, 1944, about 15,000 Canadian troops captured Juno Beach
Remembrance Day: November 11, honours over 110,000 who gave their lives
OTHER KEY DATES:
Newfoundland and Labrador joined Canada in 1949 (last province)
Nunavut became a territory in 1999
Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms entrenched in Constitution (1982)

topics.name: Modern Canada
topics.summary: Post-war Canada developed into a prosperous, diverse nation with strong international engagement.
keyFacts: ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT:
Oil discovered in Alberta in 1947 (at Leduc), launching modern energy industry
NAFTA trade agreement with US and Mexico (1994), replaced by USMCA (2020)
SOCIAL PROGRAMS:
Old Age Security (OAS) established in 1927
Employment Insurance (originally Unemployment Insurance) introduced federally in 1940
Canada and Quebec Pension Plans (CPP/QPP) created in 1965
INTERNATIONAL ENGAGEMENT:
Canada joined NATO (1949) and NORAD (North American Aerospace Defense Command) with the US
Korean War (1950-53): 26,000 Canadians served, 516 killed, over 1,000 wounded
Canada has participated in numerous UN peacekeeping missions
QUEBEC AND LANGUAGE:
Quiet Revolution: rapid modernization of Quebec in the 1960s (secularization, modernized education and healthcare)
Official Languages Act (1969) guarantees French and English services in federal government
Quebec sovereignty referendums: 1980 (defeated) and 1995 (defeated narrowly, 50.58% No)
SPORTS FIGURES:
Paul Henderson (1972): scored 'the goal heard around the world' in Canada-Soviet Summit Series
Terry Fox (1980): young British Columbian who lost his leg to cancer, ran Marathon of Hope for cancer research
Rick Hansen (1985): wheelchair circumnavigation of the globe for spinal cord research
Wayne Gretzky: legendary hockey player (Edmonton Oilers, 1979-1988)
Donovan Bailey (1996): Olympic sprinter and gold medalist
Chantal Petitclerc: Paralympic wheelchair racer
CANADIAN INVENTIONS AND INVENTORS:
Alexander Graham Bell: invented the telephone (idea came at his summer house in Canada)
Sir Frederick Banting and Charles Best: discovered insulin (saved 16 million lives worldwide)
Joseph-Armand Bombardier: invented the snowmobile
Sir Sandford Fleming: invented standard time zones
Mathew Evans and Henry Woodward: invented the electric light bulb
Reginald Fessenden: first wireless voice transmission
Dr. Wilder Penfield: pioneering brain surgery
Dr. John A. Hopps: invented the first cardiac pacemaker
SPAR Aerospace / National Research Council: Canadarm robotic arm (used on Space Shuttle and ISS)
Mike Lazaridis and Jim Balsillie: created the BlackBerry wireless device
James Naismith: Canadian who invented basketball in 1891

topics.name: How Canadians Govern Themselves
topics.summary: Canada is a federal state, a parliamentary democracy, and a constitutional monarchy.
keyFacts: Three key facts: federal state, parliamentary democracy, constitutional monarchy
Canada is the second largest country in the world (after Russia)
United States borders Canada on the south
HEAD OF STATE AND GOVERNMENT:
Head of State: The Sovereign (King or Queen), guardian of Constitutional freedoms
Head of Government: The Prime Minister (selects Cabinet, directs operations and policy)
The Crown has been a symbol of the state for 400 years (Parliament, legislatures, courts, police, Canadian Forces)
PARLIAMENT:
Parliament has three parts: Sovereign, Senate, House of Commons
Governor General represents Sovereign in Canada
Lieutenant Governors represent Sovereign in provinces
Commissioners represent the federal government in territories
Senators are appointed by Governor General on advice of PM, serve until age 75
Parliament Buildings are located in Ottawa, on Parliament Hill
HOW A BILL BECOMES LAW:
A proposed law is called a 'bill'
A bill must pass three readings in both the House of Commons and the Senate
After passing both chambers, the Governor General grants royal assent
RESPONSIBLE GOVERNMENT:
Responsible government: ministers must have support of a majority of elected representatives
If ministers lose a confidence vote in the House of Commons, they must resign
Opposition parties oppose or try to improve government proposals
THREE LEVELS OF GOVERNMENT:
10 provinces and 3 territories
Three levels: federal, provincial/territorial, municipal
Federal: defence, foreign policy, citizenship, criminal law, currency
Provincial: education, health, natural resources, highways
Municipal: local services, policing, firefighting, snow removal
English and French have equal status in Parliament of Canada
Most French-speaking Canadians live in Quebec
Premier is head of a provincial government
CITIZENSHIP:
Oath of Citizenship: pledge allegiance to the King, observe the laws of Canada, fulfil duties as a Canadian

topics.name: Federal Elections
topics.summary: Canadians elect members of Parliament who represent them in the House of Commons.
keyFacts: 338 electoral districts (ridings/constituencies) across Canada
Federal elections held third Monday in October every four years
WHO CAN VOTE AND RUN:
Must be Canadian citizen, 18+ years old to vote, and on the voters' list
Any Canadian citizen who is at least 18 years old can run as a candidate
Manitoba was the first province to grant women voting rights (1916)
VOTING PROCESS:
Electoral district (riding/constituency): geographical area represented by one MP
Voter information card: tells you when and where to vote
If no card received, contact Elections Canada or visit their website
Secret ballot: no one can watch you vote or see how you voted
On the ballot, mark an 'X' next to your chosen candidate
Election day: show voter card and ID, mark X, poll officials tear off ballot number, deposit in ballot box
You are not required to tell anyone how you voted (employer, family, union cannot demand this)
GOVERNMENT FORMATION:
Candidate with most votes in each district becomes MP
MPs represent everyone in their electoral district (not just those who voted for them)
Party with most seats forms government, leader becomes PM
Cabinet Ministers are chosen by the Prime Minister
Majority government: party holds at least half the seats
Minority government: party holds less than half the seats
Official Opposition ('Her Majesty's Loyal Opposition'): party with second-most seats
ELECTION ADMINISTRATION:
Elections Canada manages federal elections
National Register of Electors: permanent database of eligible voters

topics.name: The Justice System
topics.summary: Canada's justice system guarantees everyone due process under the law and is founded on the presumption of innocence.
keyFacts: Presumption of innocence: everyone is innocent until proven guilty
Rule of law: everyone, including the government, must follow the law; no one is above the law
Due process: government must respect all legal rights
Courts settle disputes and interpret laws fairly
COURT SYSTEM:
Supreme Court of Canada is the highest court (nine justices, decisions are final)
Federal Court deals with federal government matters
Provincial courts handle most cases
POLICE:
Police keep people safe and enforce laws
RCMP (Royal Canadian Mounted Police) is national police force, established 1873 as North West Mounted Police
Provincial police: Ontario (OPP) and Quebec (SQ) have their own forces
Municipal police in major cities
You can question police about their service or conduct

topics.name: Canadian Symbols
topics.summary: Canada has many important symbols that help explain what it means to be Canadian.
keyFacts: THE CROWN:
The Crown is a symbol of government for 400 years: Parliament, legislatures, courts, police, Canadian Forces
FLAGS AND COLOURS:
Current flag raised February 15, 1965: white with red bars on each end and red maple leaf in centre
Before 1965, Canada used the Canadian Red Ensign (featuring the Union Jack)
National colours: red and white (assigned by King George V in 1921)
The Union Jack remains the official Royal Flag of Canada
NATIONAL SYMBOLS:
Maple leaf: best-known Canadian symbol (on military insignia since the 1850s)
Beaver: official animal symbol (on the five-cent coin)
Fleur-de-lys: symbol of French royalty for 1,000+ years; on Quebec's flag (adopted 1948)
National motto: 'A Mari Usque Ad Mare' (from sea to sea), on the Coat of Arms
ANTHEM AND MUSIC:
National anthem: 'O Canada' (proclaimed 1980, first sung in Quebec City in 1880)
First line: 'O Canada! Our home and native land!'
Royal Anthem: 'God Save the King' (or Queen), played in presence of Sovereign or Governor General
SPORTS:
National winter sport: ice hockey (developed in Canada in the 1800s)
National summer sport: lacrosse (first played by Aboriginal peoples)
Stanley Cup: championship hockey trophy (donated 1892)
James Naismith: Canadian who invented basketball in 1891
HONOURS:
Victoria Cross: highest honour for bravery; 96 Canadians have received it since 1854
Order of Canada: highest civilian honour, started in 1967
PARLIAMENT BUILDINGS:
Peace Tower: completed 1927 in memory of WWI; Memorial Chamber contains Books of Remembrance with names of fallen soldiers, sailors, and airmen
Remembrance Day poppy: honours fallen soldiers
NATIONAL HOLIDAYS:
Canada Day: July 1
Victoria Day: Monday before May 25
Remembrance Day: November 11
Thanksgiving: second Monday in October
Labour Day: first Monday in September
Boxing Day: December 26

topics.name: Canada's Economy
topics.summary: Canada is a trading nation with one of the world's ten largest economies.
keyFacts: One of the ten largest economies in the world
Part of G7 (formerly G8) group of leading industrialized countries
INDUSTRY TYPES:
Three main industry types: service, manufacturing, natural resources
Over 75% of Canadians work in service industries
Service: transportation, education, healthcare, banking, retail, tourism
Manufacturing: paper, aerospace, automobiles, machinery, food
Natural resources: forestry, fishing, agriculture, mining, energy
Central Canada (Ontario and Quebec) is the industrial and manufacturing heartland
TRADE:
Largest trading partner: United States
Over 75% of Canadian exports go to the United States
Free trade with US (1988), NAFTA with US and Mexico (1994), replaced by USMCA (2020)
Trade with other countries enhances Canada's economy and raises standard of living
Port of Vancouver is Canada's largest and busiest port (Pacific Gateway)
Voyageurs: Montreal-based traders who travelled by canoe (early fur trade economy)
KEY PROVINCIAL ECONOMIES:
Oil discovered in Alberta (1947) began modern energy industry
Quebec is main producer of pulp and paper and hydro-electricity
Health and Education are provincial/territorial responsibilities

topics.name: Canada's Regions
topics.summary: Canada is the second largest country on earth with 10 provinces, 3 territories, and diverse regions.
keyFacts: OVERVIEW:
10 provinces and 3 territories
Five regions: Atlantic, Central, Prairie, West Coast, and North
Bordered by three oceans: Pacific (west), Atlantic (east), Arctic (north)
Population: about 34 million
National Capital: Ottawa (chosen by Queen Victoria in 1857)
Smallest province: Prince Edward Island (PEI)
Newest territory: Nunavut (NU) created in 1999
Last province to join: Newfoundland and Labrador (NL) in 1949
Largest city: Toronto (capital of Ontario, also main financial centre)
Second largest city: Montreal (in Quebec)
GEOGRAPHIC HIGHLIGHTS:
Lake Superior: largest freshwater lake in the world (one of five Great Lakes between Ontario and the US)
Great Lakes: Superior, Michigan, Huron, Erie, Ontario
Mount Logan (Yukon): highest mountain in Canada, named after geologist Sir William Logan
St. Lawrence River: major river in Quebec connecting Great Lakes to the Atlantic
Bay of Fundy (Nova Scotia): world's highest tides
REGIONAL GROUPINGS:
Atlantic Provinces: Newfoundland and Labrador (NL), Prince Edward Island (PEI), Nova Scotia (NS), New Brunswick (NB)
Central Canada: Quebec (QC) and Ontario (ON) - home to more than half of Canada's population
Prairie Provinces: Manitoba (MB), Saskatchewan (SK), Alberta (AB) - fertile farmland and energy resources
West Coast: British Columbia (BC)
Northern Territories: Yukon (YT), Northwest Territories (NT), Nunavut (NU)
PROVINCIAL CAPITALS (West to East):
British Columbia (BC): Victoria (on Vancouver Island, tourist centre, navy's Pacific fleet HQ)
Alberta (AB): Edmonton
Saskatchewan (SK): Regina (home to RCMP training academy)
Manitoba (MB): Winnipeg
Ontario (ON): Toronto
Quebec (QC): Quebec City
New Brunswick (NB): Fredericton
Nova Scotia (NS): Halifax
Prince Edward Island (PEI): Charlottetown
Newfoundland and Labrador (NL): St. John's
TERRITORIAL CAPITALS:
Yukon (YT): Whitehorse
Northwest Territories (NT): Yellowknife
Nunavut (NU): Iqaluit
NOTABLE PROVINCIAL FACTS:
One third of all Canadians live in Ontario
PEI is the 'birthplace of Confederation' (first meetings in Charlottetown, 1864)
PEI: known for beaches, red soil, and potatoes
Saskatchewan: 'breadbasket of the world' with 40% of Canada's arable land, largest grain and oilseed producer
Alberta: largest producer of oil and gas in Canada, vast cattle ranches
Newfoundland and Labrador has its own time zone (Newfoundland Time, 30 min ahead of Atlantic)
PROVINCIAL ECONOMIES:
British Columbia (BC): Forests, fish, water resources, Pacific Gateway for trade
Alberta (AB): Oil, natural gas, agriculture, forestry
Saskatchewan (SK): Farming, mining (potash), natural gas (Canada's breadbasket)
Manitoba (MB): Agriculture, mining, hydro-electric power generation
Ontario (ON): Mining, tourism, automobile manufacturing (Industrial heartland)
Quebec (QC): Pulp and paper, forestry, hydro-electric power
New Brunswick (NB): Forestry, agriculture, mining
Nova Scotia (NS): Coal mining, forestry, agriculture
Prince Edward Island (PEI): Agriculture, fishing, tourism
Newfoundland and Labrador (NL): Fisheries, oil and gas extraction
NORTHERN TERRITORIES:
Northern Territories cover more than one-third of Canada's land area
Known as 'Land of the Midnight Sun' (up to 24 hours of daylight in summer)
Nunavut: about 85% Inuit population; Inuktitut is official language and first language in schools
PROVINCIAL GOVERNMENT STRUCTURE:
Premier: Head of provincial government (elected)
Lieutenant Governor: Represents the Sovereign in each province
Official Opposition: Party with second-most seats in provincial legislature
Provincial legislatures handle: health, education, natural resources
Note: Political leaders change with elections
TERRITORIAL GOVERNMENT STRUCTURE:
Commissioner: Represents federal government in territories
Premier: Head of territorial government
Northwest Territories and Nunavut: Consensus government (no political parties)
Yukon: Party system similar to provinces
